Award.AwardTitle: Meeting: Support of Student Participation in the 2017 International Congress on Membranes and Membrane Processes, July 29-August4, 2017, San Franciso, CA

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Separation of a complex chemical mixture into its molecular components requires energy, and it is estimated that 10 to 15% of the world?s energy goes into the separation of chemical products and precursors, including gasoline, polymer precursors, drinking water, and pharmaceuticals. A number of new separation processes, based on molecular-level interactions and molecular sieving effects, are being developed to reduce this parasitic energy consumption of purification. Membranes are an emerging technology that generally use significantly less energy than traditional separation processes, as they do not require a phase change (such as boiling) to separate the constituents on a molecular basis. Rather, the membranes serves as a selective boundary that allows a molecule of one type to pass while retaining other molecules. Due in part to the reduced energy consumption, nearly 8% growth is expected in the membrane markets for gas and liquid separations through 2019, and student involvement and engagement is essential to support growth of this community.

The International Congress on Membranes and Membrane Processes meeting is one of the preeminent global membrane meetings, and is held every three years. It is a cooperative meeting between three international societies, including the North America Membrane Society of the US. The latest developments in the membrane field from leading academic, governmental, and industrial laboratories are presented for the first time for evaluation by the membrane community. Enabling Membrane Technology is the theme of the 2017 meeting, as adoption of energy-efficient membrane technology has been hindered by the risks associated with replacing traditional separation technology on a large scale. This project supports graduate student participation in the 11th meeting of this group, which will be held July 29 - August 4, 2017 in San Francisco, CA at the Hilton San Francisco Union Square. Up to 150 students will be selected from US Universities to receive $100 per person to offset registration fees. Travel supplements offered by the North America Membrane Society will be used synergistically to support student travel. Travel to this conference will enable students to network with their peers and understand their work in the context of the larger field. The feedback the students receive from senior members of the community can help direct their career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2017 International Congress on Membranes and Membrane Processes (ICOM) was held July 29 – August 4, 2017 at the Hilton San Francisco Union Square in San Francisco, California. ICOM meetings are organized by the three major global membrane professional societies: 1) North American Membrane Society, 2) European Membrane Society, and 3) Aseanian Membrane Society. The meetings are held triennially rotating between the three continents. The last ICOM held in North America was in 2008 and the next will be in 2026. Given this rotation, North America hosts the meeting once every nine years. Thus, the 2017 meeting offered an unprecedented opportunity for those in the United States to interact with the global membrane community.

 

As one of the preeminent membrane meetings, ICOM attracts attendance from academic, industrial, and governmental thought leaders in the field. The most recent work of the community is presented for evaluation and feedback.

 

Membranes play a crucial role in addressing the grand challenges facing society in the production of water, materials, energy, and food. Specific application areas include carbon dioxide capture and sequestration, drinking water production by desalination, waste water treatment, production of industrial chemicals such as nitrogen and ammonia, and production of natural gas for energy and chemical uses. Sessions in these and related areas were held at the meeting.

 

Membrane processes offer the potential to address these challenges while minimizing energy consumption. Reduced energy consumption can dramatically lower costs and simultaneously reduce greenhouse gas emissions and the demand for energy imports.

 

ICOM 2017 focused on “Enabling Membrane Technology”. While membrane technology offers substantial energetic and economic advantages, industrial adoption is hampered by potential risks associated with replacing well established conventional processes. Participation in ICOM 2017 let students learn about these issues and present their work for feedback from peers and more senior members of the field. Such feedback helps focus their efforts and supports their professional development.

 

The financial support provided by the National Science Foundation facilitated student participation by partially offsetting attendance costs. 105 students at 38 different academic institutions received $100. The total funding exceeded that provided by NSF – the difference was provided from conference revenue. The number of students reflects the impact of NSF support on student participation.

 

A special student workshop was held prior to the start of the technical conference. The “Young Membranologists Workshop” included sessions on careers in industry, careers in academia, entrepreneurship and spin-off companies, as well as a panel discussion devoted to helping students find their own career path. Additionally, a tour of the gas separation membrane manufacturing plant operated by Generon IGS in Pittsburg, California was offered prior to the workshop. A photo of the group at the plant accompanies this report.

 

A great need exists for students skilled in membrane science and engineering. The industry is expected to grow by nearly 8% in myriad gas and liquid separation markets through 2019. Such growth will require a pool of potential employees.

 

In addition to development of human resources for the membrane industry, NSF support allowed students to share their latest research with attendees. This showcase of student efforts to develop new materials and technologies attracts significant industrial participation and allows industry to evaluate the potential for commercialization of the innovations reported. The economic growth associated with such commercialization benefits the entire country.

 

The importance of this interaction was recognized by encouraging students to present a poster at one of the two posters sessions and having their work evaluated by a group of judges. 20 posters were selected for awards from approximately 250 presentations.
